Blog/ Making my CSS Sassy

Date: 13th March 17

All About Sass

As a self-initiated project, I decided to explore Sass. The aim is to implement Sass techniques into my portfolio site. The objectives of this project are to research about Sass through various tutorials, to illustrate basic Sass techniques, to evaluate the Sass used and the performance of the code by having unrepeated unnecessary code and to use variables to create a standard style across the site to illustrate the efficiencies of Sass.

“Sass is the most mature, stable, and powerful professional grade CSS extension language in the world.”(sass, No Date: online).

I wanted to look into Sass after having some feedback from my previous work about having repeated code. When I looked into this I saw that Sass was used to help organise CSS and helped to produce DRY code. Dry or “Don’t repeat yourself,” is a programming principle coined in The Pragmatic Programmer (Hunt,Thomas,1999) that states;

“Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.”

I then came across the different CSS pre-processors, SCSS, SASS and LESS. I asked my friends as well as researched to learn the differences and SCSS came out as the best one to learn due to it being the most similar to CSS.

“Sass has two syntaxes. The most commonly used syntax is known as “SCSS” (for “Sassy CSS”), and is a superset of CSS3’s syntax. This means that every valid CSS3 stylesheet is valid SCSS as well. SCSS files use the extension .scss.” (Avery,2013:online).

Lets get Sassy....

Similarly, to my other self-initiated project I went about building knowledge by watching some tutorials. I started with the Lynda video called Sass Essential Training . The concept of Sass seemed okay in my head until it came to watching videos of people doing it, then it seemed quite confusing. The most confusing part for me was learning that I work within the .SCSS file and the CSS file is then the outputted version. I have been using WebStorm to write my code in and find it great and it has built in File Watchers that translate SCSS to CSS but just to make things more interesting I also wanted to learn how to use Gulp. Luckily I have a very knowledgeable friend who was willing to help me out with any questions I had, I followed the CSS tricks post on Gulp for beginners. This was brilliant to follow and allowed me to set up live browser reloading with browserSync and it allowed me to use Gulp plugins to minify my JS,HTML and images and send to my dist/distribution folder.

“We can compile Sass to CSS in Gulp with the help of a plugin called gulp-sass.” (Liew, 2015: online)

I then went to do a Sass course on Code School called Assembling Sass, the process of what Sass does is logical, it made sense to me as it reduces the need for repeated code and allows for a more organised stylesheet. Even though I thought I knew what Sass was all about I was still missing the part of applying it to my own work, this is when I knew I got the concept but not exactly how to apply it.

By looking at other people using Sass in their projects it enabled me to see exactly how it is used and which areas are more widely used. This for me was the point where is clicked into place, I saw the theory that I had learnt put into practice and felt more confident in applying it to my portfolio site.

How i put it into practice....

I wanted to put what I had learnt so far into practice and I decided to change my CSS for this site into SCSS. This gave me a new look on how to organise my stylesheet. The first thing I decided to do was create a variable which would hold a colour. This was my main colour ( #339999) so I called it $maincolour and used it where I had put borders or similar in the main colour of my site. All my main headings were also in this colour but I decided to give them a separate variable in case I wanted to change the colour later, $headingcolour.

I did some nesting but researched and found out that you can nest too deep and it can get confusing and hard work, one article on nesting in Sass explained it well. The general thoughts are you haven’t to nest any deeper than 3 levels (Powell, 2014) and it is best to keep it to simple things such as hover. Below is a hover example on a button, the & allows there to be no space when it is compiled into CSS so it forms a.btn:hover rather than a.btn :hover.

@import

I decided to import both extend and variables but also different sections. I decided to start by just importing the main sections that occurred on all the pages so in my case it was my header, footer and my nav.

“So, you have the benefits of a single file download, with the flexibility of multiple files that contain reusable code.” (Coyier, 2013: online)

@extend

I decided to use the @extend function for my H1 and where I have repeated used the same Flexbox back up properties for different browsers. I have recently had a talk from Harry Roberts (CSS Wizardry) and he explained that it is better for performance to use Mixins rather than Extend as there is more repetition in the CSS when using Mixins and therefore they gzip better (Roberts, 2016). This is something I would do if it was a larger site or as I become more comfortable and start using the available Sass features more.

CodePen

I also had a go at using the colour Sass functions available to make a colour palette(sass, no date) and using a Sass Map to put colours onto SVG images. This is a really cool idea as it could be used for colour pallets for websites and allows easy colour changes.

See the Pen Colours - Sass by Philippa (@philippabone) on CodePen.

See the Pen Data Map - Sass by Philippa (@philippabone) on CodePen.

Conclusion

This project has enabled me to see another dimension to stylesheets, I know I have only scratched the surface with Sass but I plan on carrying on learning and improving both this site and any future sites. Sass will allow me to have more DRY code, more organised code and code that people can take on easier!
